questions.question: It was such a comic state of affairs ……………………….. we had to laugh.
questions.description: The correlative conjunction used in this structure is such...that.

questions.question: The negotiations collapsed …………………………. no agreement could be reached.
questions.description: All of the above can be used here with slightly different meanings.

questions.question: I like you better …………………………… I like him.
questions.description: In comparative expressions we use than.

questions.question: I will need the car …………………………….. you will have to hire a taxi.
questions.description: We cannot use then to connect two ideas spoken by the same speaker.

questions.question: ‘I will be busy in the morning’. ‘………………………. I will come in the afternoon.’
questions.description: Then is used when one speaker replies to another.

questions.question: Many things have happened ………………………….. we last met.
questions.description: Since can indicate time. It is mainly used with perfect tenses.

questions.question: Janet can sing beautifully and …………………………… can her sister.
questions.description: This structure with so is used to add to the sentence before.

questions.question: I scored good marks, …………………………….. I had not prepared for the exam.
questions.description: Even though has a past reference. It is an emphatic form of though and although.

questions.question: She says that she will come …………………………….. there is a bus strike next week.
questions.description: Even if has a future reference.

questions.question: Grievances cannot be addressed …………………………………. they are spoken about.
